sequence_types.name: T1
sequence_types.pulse_sequence_info: Fast Spin Echo (FSE/TSE) - Uses multiple 180-degree refocusing pulses to generate echoes. Produces clean images with reduced susceptibility artifacts.

rationale.purpose: Provides excellent anatomic detail with high signal from fat and proteinaceous fluid
limitations: Fat can obscure pathology (use fat sat if needed)
Less sensitive to acute stroke than DWI
clinical_pearls: Always obtain before contrast to assess for intrinsic T1 shortening
Methemoglobin in subacute blood is bright on T1

sequence_types.name: T2
sequence_types.pulse_sequence_info: Fast Spin Echo (FSE/TSE) - Standard T2 uses spin echo technique for excellent fluid sensitivity with minimal susceptibility artifact.

rationale.purpose: Highly sensitive to water/fluid content - the workhorse for detecting pathology
what_it_shows: Most pathology appears bright due to increased water
limitations: Bright CSF can obscure periventricular lesions (use FLAIR)
clinical_pearls: If it's bright on T2, think water/pathology
Compare with FLAIR to distinguish CSF from pathology

sequence_types.name: T2 FS
sequence_types.pulse_sequence_info: Fast Spin Echo with frequency-selective fat saturation. Fat sat pulse applied before each excitation to null fat signal.

rationale.purpose: T2 with fat signal suppressed - better visualization of edema in fatty tissues
what_it_shows: Bone marrow edema (bright against dark fat)
limitations: Fat sat can fail near metal or air-tissue interfaces
clinical_pearls: Essential for orbits - optic neuritis shows bright nerve on T2 FS
Bone marrow edema pattern helps date fractures

sequence_types.name: FLAIR
sequence_types.pulse_sequence_info: Fast Spin Echo with Inversion Recovery. An inversion pulse nulls CSF signal at TI ~2000-2500ms, making periventricular lesions conspicuous.

rationale.purpose: T2-weighted with CSF signal suppressed - ideal for periventricular and cortical lesions
limitations: Longer scan time than standard T2
Less useful in posterior fossa (CSF pulsation)
clinical_pearls: Essential for MS protocols - count lesions on FLAIR
Bright FLAIR signal in sulci = SAH or meningitis
Sagittal FLAIR shows Dawson fingers at callososeptal interface

sequence_types.name: DWI
sequence_types.pulse_sequence_info: Echo Planar Imaging (EPI) - Single-shot acquisition enabling rapid diffusion encoding. Very fast but prone to geometric distortion near air/bone interfaces.

rationale.purpose: Detects restricted water diffusion - critical for acute stroke and high cellularity
what_it_shows: Must confirm with ADC map (true restriction = dark ADC)
limitations: T2 shine-through can mimic restriction (check ADC)
clinical_pearls: Stroke protocol: DWI is the money sequence
Always look at ADC - bright DWI + bright ADC = T2 shine-through
ADC is auto-generated, no extra scan time

sequence_types.name: SWI
sequence_types.pulse_sequence_info: Gradient Recalled Echo (GRE) - Uses gradient refocusing instead of 180-degree pulse. Highly sensitive to magnetic susceptibility differences (blood, calcium, iron).

rationale.purpose: Exquisitely sensitive to blood products, calcium, and iron deposition
limitations: Cannot distinguish acute from chronic blood
clinical_pearls: Count microbleeds in TBI and dementia workup
Phase images help distinguish calcium (bright) from blood (dark)

sequence_types.name: STIR
sequence_types.pulse_sequence_info: Fast Spin Echo with Short Tau Inversion Recovery. TI ~150ms nulls fat signal. More robust fat suppression than frequency-selective methods, works near metal.

rationale.purpose: Robust fat suppression via inversion recovery - works even near metal
when_to_use: Near hardware where fat sat fails
limitations: Lower SNR than T2 fat sat
Fluid in joints can be very bright
clinical_pearls: STIR is the workhorse for whole-body MRI screening
More reliable fat suppression than frequency-selective fat sat
Acute compression fracture = bright marrow edema

sequence_types.name: PD FS
sequence_types.pulse_sequence_info: Fast Spin Echo with intermediate TE (short TE, long TR). Optimized for cartilage and meniscus evaluation with high SNR.

rationale.purpose: Optimal for cartilage and fibrocartilage evaluation - the MSK workhorse
limitations: Less sensitive to bone marrow edema than STIR
clinical_pearls: Meniscal tear = linear signal reaching articular surface
Cartilage is intermediate signal - focal defects are pathologic
ACL should appear as a taut, low-signal band

sequence_types.name: T1+C
sequence_types.pulse_sequence_info: Fast Spin Echo T1-weighted acquired after gadolinium administration. Enhancement indicates BBB breakdown or hypervascularity.

rationale.purpose: Detect blood-brain barrier breakdown and vascular lesions
limitations: Cannot distinguish tumor from treatment effect alone
Need pre-contrast T1 to confirm enhancement
clinical_pearls: Compare directly with pre-contrast T1 to confirm enhancement
Ring enhancement: tumor, abscess, or demyelination

sequence_types.name: T1 FS+C
sequence_types.pulse_sequence_info: Fast Spin Echo T1 with fat saturation, post-gadolinium. Fat suppression prevents fat from mimicking enhancement.

rationale.purpose: Post-contrast with fat suppression - better enhancement visibility in fatty tissues
limitations: Fat sat can fail near hardware
clinical_pearls: Essential for spine tumor protocols
Fat sat prevents fat from mimicking enhancement

sequence_types.name: 3D MPRAGE
sequence_types.pulse_sequence_info: 3D Gradient Echo with Inversion Recovery preparation. Creates excellent gray-white contrast with thin isotropic slices for volumetric analysis.

rationale.purpose: High-resolution 3D T1 for volumetric analysis and multiplanar reformats
what_it_shows: Isotropic voxels allow any reformat plane
clinical_pearls: 1mm isotropic allows reformats in any plane
Use for hippocampal volumetrics in dementia

sequence_types.name: 3D MPRAGE+C
sequence_types.pulse_sequence_info: 3D MPRAGE acquired after gadolinium. Thin slices improve small lesion detection (metastases, cranial nerve enhancement).

rationale.purpose: High-resolution 3D post-contrast for small enhancing lesions
clinical_pearls: Higher sensitivity for small metastases than 2D
Can reformat in any plane post-acquisition

sequence_types.name: 3D TOF MRA
sequence_types.pulse_sequence_info: Time-of-Flight GRE using inflow enhancement. Fresh blood entering the slab appears bright (flow-related enhancement).

rationale.purpose: Non-contrast arterial imaging using flow-related enhancement
limitations: Slow flow may not be seen
clinical_pearls: Always review source images - MIP can hide small aneurysms
Compare with CTA if aneurysm morphology critical

sequence_types.name: MRA Neck
sequence_types.pulse_sequence_info: Time-of-Flight GRE for cervical vessels. Multiple overlapping thin slabs cover the neck vasculature.

rationale.purpose: Non-contrast evaluation of cervical carotid and vertebral arteries
clinical_pearls: Compare with carotid ultrasound
Consider CE-MRA for more accurate stenosis grading

sequence_types.name: MRV
sequence_types.pulse_sequence_info: Phase Contrast GRE - Uses velocity-encoding gradients to image flowing blood. Can be 2D (thick slab projection) or 3D (volumetric).

rationale.purpose: Evaluate cerebral venous sinuses without contrast
limitations: Flow gaps at sinus confluences are normal
Slow flow may cause signal loss
clinical_pearls: Correlate with T1/T2 for thrombus signal
Dominant transverse sinus is normal variant

sequence_types.name: MRCP
sequence_types.pulse_sequence_info: Heavily T2-weighted 3D Fast Spin Echo. Very long TE makes static fluid (bile, pancreatic juice) appear bright while suppressing background tissue.

rationale.purpose: Non-invasive biliary and pancreatic duct imaging
clinical_pearls: Always review source images, not just MIP
CBD >7mm post-cholecystectomy may be normal

sequence_types.name: Dynamic
sequence_types.pulse_sequence_info: Fast 3D Gradient Echo (VIBE/LAVA/THRIVE) with fat sat. Rapid acquisition enables multiphasic imaging during contrast wash-in and wash-out.

rationale.purpose: Multiphasic imaging to characterize lesions by enhancement pattern
what_it_shows: Portal venous phase: most lesion detection
limitations: Timing is critical - need bolus tracking
clinical_pearls: HCC: arterial enhancement + portal venous washout
Use LI-RADS criteria for standardized reporting

sequence_types.name: HASTE
sequence_types.pulse_sequence_info: Single-Shot Fast Spin Echo (HASTE/SS-TSE) - Entire k-space filled in one shot. Ultrafast acquisition (<1 sec/slice) reduces motion artifact.

rationale.purpose: Ultrafast T2 imaging - single breath hold per slice
clinical_pearls: Useful for uncooperative patients
Can acquire during free breathing
